visual_elements.description: A four-column table defining how to measure grade in different situations. The columns are 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.' (Illustrations). It lists three scenarios: 'The height of a structure on land with natural slope ≤ 10%', 'The height of a structure on land with natural slope > 10%', and 'A daylight plane'.

Figure 44, titled 'Existing vs. Finished grade'. It shows a side elevation of a two-story house with a chimney. It illustrates the difference between 'Existing grade (before fill)' (a lower, dashed line) and 'Finished grade (after fill)' (a higher, solid line). A vertical arrow indicates 'Height: measured to top of roof material of the highest peak'. An arrow points to the 'Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure'. A small number '12' is visible on the roof slope.

Figure 45, titled 'Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%'. It depicts two houses built on a steep, terraced slope. It shows the 'Existing grade (before fill)' as a dashed line. Two parallel dashed lines above the houses represent height limits: '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished'. Vertical arrows labeled 'Height' measure from the ground to the roof peak of each house. A text box explains: 'The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope'.

Figure 46, titled 'Comparison of different grades'. This is a line chart on a grid. It shows four diagonal lines originating from the bottom-right corner, representing different slope gradients. Each line is labeled with its ratio and percentage: '1:10 10%', '3:10 33%', '5:10 50%', and '10:10 100%'.

Slope condition for height limits in Fig 45

subheadings: Fig 45 Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%
sections: Table Column: Which is defined as

additional_notes: The page number '47' is located in the bottom-right corner.
The overall layout consists of a table on the upper left, a diagram on the upper right, another diagram on the lower left, and a chart on the lower right.
In the table, under the 'Which is defined as' column for 'natural slope > 10%', the words 'at any' are emphasized with a style that mimics handwriting or an underline.
In Figure 44, the label 'Existing grade (before fill)' near the foundation is partially obscured or overwritten, but remains legible.
